headline: Man Utd manager was sacked just hours after Red Devils were told to wield axe
body: Erik ten Hag's sacking at Manchester United came just hours after the Premier League side were told to ditch the Dutchman by Jamie O'Hara. The 55-year-old was dismissed from his role at Old Trafford last October, just one day after his side lost 2-1 to West Ham at the London Stadium.

With the Red Devils taking on the east London side on Sunday, it's the first time they'll do so since the first match between the two sides sparked the sacking of Ten Hag after over two years in charge.
The defeat was United's fourth in just nine league games and saw them languishing 14th in the table and it was eventually too much for the club's hierarchy to accept.

However, before the decision came down to remove the ex-Ajax boss from his job, Sir Jim Ratcliffe was told to do just that by O'Hara, who called on the 13-time Premier League champions to get rid of him.

"I'd get rid of him; I would have gotten rid of him three months ago," he said. "I wouldn't have gave him a contract after the FA Cup, I'd have said, 'Thanks very much, you've finished with a trophy, go out on a high.
"They should have got something from the game today but overall they've been poor. I've watched them in the Europa League as well and they've been poor."

The pundit was proved right as less than 24 hours later, Ten Hag was sacked with United confirming their decision in a statement. It read: "We are grateful to Erik for everything he has done during his time with us and wish him well for the future.

"Ruud van Nistelrooy will take charge of the team as interim head coach, supported by the current coaching team, whilst a permanent head coach is recruited." While Amorim arrived over two weeks later, United's form only got worse and have remained in the bottom half since Christmas and currently sit 15th with three games to go.
However, the Portuguese boss is on the verge of delivering a European trophy in his first season with his side set to duke it out with Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final later this month.
There have been changes at West Ham also, as Julen Lopetegui was relieved of his duties in early January, four days after their 4-1 loss at Manchester City.

It was ex-Chelsea boss Graham Potter who was appointed as the Spaniard's replacement, but the Hammers' fortunes haven't changed much. They've earned just three league wins in their last 15 games as they sit a lowly 17th.

headline: Why Man Utd will wear different home shirt for Premier League clash with West Ham
body: Manchester United will take advantage of a little-known Football Association rule to wear a different home shirt for Sunday's clash with West Ham. The Red Devils will host Graham Potter's side with three games to go in the Premier League season.
On Thursday, Ruben Amorim's men booked their place in the final of the Europa League. Amorim has already admitted that his full attention now rests on that game in Bilbao in a fortnight.
But club chiefs are keen to finish the season strongly, with United sitting down in 15th. The Red Devils will be making history on Sunday by swapping out their iconic home shirt for the first time.
Instead of their normal kit, United will wear a special-edition shirt for the visit of the Hammers. The kit will bear the logo of the RED charity, in place of usual sponsors Snapdragon.

The technology brand have donated their logo space to promote RED's life-saving work through its Global Fund, which focuses on tackling the world's deadliest pandemics, including HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria.

To change kits, United have taken advantage of the little-known section 6(d) of the FA's Kit and Advertising Regulations. The rule allows clubs to temporarily replace their main shirt sponsor with the logo of a charitable organisation for up to three charities a season.
This will be the first time a charitable organisation has appeared on the front of a United shirt for a league fixture. The move has been backed by legendary skipper Gary Neville.

He said: "By donating the front-of-shirt logo, Snapdragon is showing the world that football can drive real change. Together, we can unite millions of fans to fight global health injustice, harnessing the power of football to make a difference and create a brighter future."

In a further move in support of the charity, United, Snapdragon and RED have collaborated with Adidas to create a limited-edition merchandise collection. All net proceeds will be donated to the Global Fund, while fans will also be able to bid for the shirts worn during the matches, with the money raised also supporting the cause.

Amorim meanwhile is focused on protecting his players ahead of the crucial final against Tottenham. He said: "What I will protect is the players that can get an injury. We have to manage that but they have to play and it is better to play than to stay out.
"Again, we cannot save anything from the Premier League. But I think it's a good thing for them as we'll not have a lot of trainings. They will fight for the places in the final in these games.

"We also have to acknowledge that we are Manchester United and we need to win games, also in the Premier League, and we have to use every game to improve, even to prepare for the final, but, especially, to prepare for the future.

"We are trying to do our best but I agree, we can do better. But I have to make a choice. What is the best for the club not what is the best for me. I make a choice in this moment [that] I'm going to try to save all the players because it's really important for us to win the final."

headline: Man Utd face possible Champions League ban for next season if they win Europa League
body: Manchester United's season has been a rollercoaster ride - but there's still a chance for them to end on a high note after they secured their spot in the Europa League final this week.

Ruben Amorim's squad demolished Athletic Club with a 7-1 aggregate victory, setting up a showdown with Tottenham Hotspur in Bilbao in just 10 days. Spurs also had an impressive run, beating Bodo/Glimt 5-1 over two legs.

Despite their struggles in domestic competitions, Ange Postecoglou's side have managed to defeat the Red Devils three times this season. For Spurs, lifting the trophy would break a 17-year drought, while for United, it could provide a silver lining to a disappointing season.
It's worth noting that the Europa League winners automatically secure a spot in next season's Champions League. However, for United, this might not be a given.

Previous UEFA rules stated that two clubs under the same ownership can't compete in different European competitions. As Sir Jim Ratcliffe has stakes in both Man United and Ligue 1 team Nice, it would have been impossible for both clubs to play in Europe.
Despite a 2-0 loss to Rennes on Saturday, Nice are well-positioned to qualify for next season's Champions League as they currently sit fourth in the Ligue 1 table.

Last year, the regulations were tweaked to accommodate multiple clubs under the same ownership, with each case being evaluated individually. This is evident in Manchester City and Girona, both part of the City Group, participating in this season's tournament.

United have already encountered issues due to Ratcliffe's involvement with Nice, as seen when Jean-Clair Todibo's move to Old Trafford was blocked. However, there are two reasons for United to remain optimistic about the situation.

Ratcliffe is reportedly considering selling the French club. If the sale goes through before a specific date, assuming United wins the Europa League and Nice secures a Champions League qualification spot, there should be no problems.

Furthermore, it has been clarified that there isn't a one-size-fits-all rule for every situation. Even if Ratcliffe retains stakes in both clubs, there's still a possibility for both to compete among Europe's top teams, as indicated by a UEFA statement.

The statement asserted that "no one is simultaneously involved, directly or indirectly, in any capacity whatsoever in the management, administration and/or sporting performance of more than one club participating in a UEFA club competition; and no one has control or decisive influence over more than one club participating in a UEFA club competition."

Therefore, all that's really required is evidence that the two clubs aren't managed concurrently. Ratcliffe's intention to sell his stake in Nice could certainly strengthen their case if the worst happens.

headline: 'I'm linked with Arsenal, Chelsea and Man Utd - Premier League transfer is my dream'
body: Patrik Schick has already made clear his desire to play in the Premier League amid reported interest from some of England's top-tier clubs. The Bayer Leverkusen striker has enjoyed an impressive season, scoring 25 goals, 19 of which came in the Bundesliga.

The German side could only claim the DFL-Supercup for silverware as Bayern Munich became league champions once again. However, Schick's return to goal-scoring prowess could result in the 29-year-old earning a move abroad. The likes of Chelsea, Manchester United, and Arsenal have been linked to signing the striker after five years at Leverkusen.

The Czech international first cut his teeth in Germany during a loan spell with RB Leipzig in the 2019/20 season from Roma. It turned out to be a success with the striker netting 10 goals in 22 league games, with the side finishing third in the league and reaching the semi-finals of the UEFA Champions League.
It was during his stint at Leipzig that Schick revealed that while he had already realised his dream of playing in Italy, the opportunity to compete in England was one that he relished.

"When I left the Czech Republic, my dream was to play in Italy and I achieved that,' he told iSport.cz in 2020. "Now, I feel very attracted to England, to be honest. Leipzig was absolutely the right choice for my career. I had also talked to Borussia Dortmund, Bayer Leverkusen and Schalke here in Germany.

"In England, there were Everton and Crystal Palace, plus Valencia in Spain. I just felt that Leipzig wanted me more, and I was also attracted to the playing style of coach Julian Nagelsmann. I am sure that I made the right choice."
Should Schick decide to end his Leverkusen journey, he'll be joining his manager, Xabi Alonso, on the way out after the Spaniard announced his intention to depart the club at the end of the season.

With Carlo Ancelotti set to leave Real Madrid this summer, Alonso is reportedly in line to replace the Italian in what would be a return to his former club. "This week the club and I have agreed that these two games are going to be my last as Bayer Leverkusen coach," the ex-Liverpool midfielder said on Friday.

"It is not a moment to talk too much about the future because we want to have a proper farewell on Sunday here for some players, for myself, and it is the right moment to announce it. We have to enjoy this moment with mixed emotions.

"It is emotional, I spoke this morning with the players, the staff, so many people who have helped me during an unbelievable, fantastic three years. Now is a moment to share it with the fans in this stadium where I have lived great emotions and become what I am right now."

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe suffers fresh Champions League blow as club sale plans hits setback
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe's plans to sell Nice have suffered a blow after the French side missed out on automatic qualification for the league phase of the Champions League. Ratcliffe, through his company Ineos, bought Nice back in the summer for 2019 for around £85million.
He has endured a rocky time at the Allianz Riviera though, with the regime deeply unpopular among supporters. Ratcliffe has increasingly turned his focus away from Nice and onto Manchester United.

Despite that lack of attention, Nice have enjoyed their most successful season yet since Ratcliffe took over. After losing manager Francesco Farioli to Ajax last summer following a fifth place finish, Franck Haise was appointed in his place.
With one game to play, Haise has all but secured European football for his side. They currently sit in fourth place, but are level on points with both Lille in fifth and Strasbourg in sixth.

Due to Ligue 1's diminishing status in European football, only the top three in Ligue 1 qualify automatically for the league phase of the Champions League. With one game remaining, Nice cannot catch third-place Monaco, who sit four points ahead of them.

Les Aiglons must beat Brest on the final day to secure their fourth place finish. But they will then face the arduous test of the qualifying rounds, with Ligue 1's fourth-place team entering at the third stage.

That would mean a two-leg play-off for Nice at the start of August, before a final play-off round at the end of that month. Nice's chances of finishing in the top three were dashed by a poor defeat away at mid-table Rennes on Saturday.
Two goals from Arnaud Kalimuendo secured the three points for the hosts. He first turned in a cross from Ludovic Blas after 15 minutes, before breaking through to finish past Marcin Bulka late on.
Missing out on automatic qualification is a serious blow for Ratcliffe's hopes of selling the team. It was revealed last week that the billionaire is looking to move on from the South of France.

He has engaged New York-based investment bank Lazard to find a buyer, with the hope of bringing in £213m. A 'blind trust' have been operating Nice this season, with neither Ineos nor Ratcliffe having 'control or decisive influence' at the club.

That was due to UEFA rules around multi-club operations as both United and Nice qualified for the Europa League. Bringing in such a large fee is already complicated by the TV rights crisis in French football.
And the potential lack of Champions League money coming in is an added blow. Ratcliffe has already made it clear he has little interest in Nice, now he has taken over at United.

"With Nice, in the French league, you can buy a club for £100million. It’s much cheaper access. But I don’t particularly enjoy going to watch Nice because there are some good players but the level of football is not high enough for me to get excited," he told The Times.

“The best season that Nice has had is this one where we’ve not been allowed to get involved because of multi-club ownership rules. They’ve been so much better without our interference! Maybe there’s a lesson there as well, you know."

headline: What happened to Glazers' very first Man Utd signings and how their careers panned out
body: It's been 20 years since the Glazer family took the reins at Manchester United. The takeover in May 2005 sparked protests from around 300 United fans outside Old Trafford, and even led to Bobby Charlton issuing a public apology to the owners for their frosty welcome.

Fast forward to 2025, and the family has splashed out more than £2billion on transfers in a bid to secure Premier League and Champions League success, yet they continue to be a bone of contention among the United faithful.

Despite Sir Jim Ratcliffe and INEOS acquiring a minority stake in the club last February, with aspirations of injecting new life into the club by taking over football operations, there's been little improvement on the pitch.
United ended up in eighth place in the 2023/24 season under Erik ten Hag, despite board support, and this season looks set to be even worse with a record low Premier League position looming.

More investment is definitely needed in the upcoming summer transfer window if the board hopes to turn things around under latest manager Ruben Amorim, but it hasn't always been doom and gloom in the north west.
In fact, some of the first signings made under the new era at Old Trafford went on to have stellar careers with the Red Devils under Sir Alex Ferguson.

Van der Sar was instrumental in helping United clinch the Premier League title in the 2006/07 season, and followed it up with a league, Community Shield, and Champions League treble the next year – showcasing his skills particularly during a nail-biting European final penalty shootout against Chelsea.

With four Premier League titles to his name, Van der Sar bid farewell to United in 2011, having made 266 appearances in total. He left as the club's best goalkeeper since Peter Schmeichel's departure in 1999.
In his post-playing career, Van der Sar became Ajax's marketing director in 2012 before being promoted in late 2016 to the role of CEO. But in May 2023, he resigned from his post.

Just a month after Van der Sar's arrival in the north west, the Red Devils secured the signing of Ji-sung Park from PSV for £4m. The midfielder's transfer marked him as only the second Asian player to sign for the club, following Dong Fangzhuo in 2004.

Although Park didn't score as many goals as fans had anticipated, he was a key part of Ferguson's squad and featured in 45 matches in his first season. Despite his second year being marred by injury, he still managed to secure a Premier League winners' medal after netting five goals in 14 games.

He was also part of the team that clinched the 2008 Champions League title, although he was left out of the squad for the final by Ferguson in a tough call. Park's most fruitful season came in 2010/11 when he netted eight goals in 28 matches before moving to QPR at the end of the season. He retired after returning to former club PSV Eindhoven for the 2013/14 season.

Park completed his coaching badges as he took charge of QPR's Under-16 side as part of his coaching B license. After leaving the west Londoners, Park joined K League 1 side Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors as their technical director in 2022. There, he appointed ex-Chelsea star Dan Petrescu as manager, but the Romanian's time in charge didn't last long as he resigned mid-season.
Park then became an advisor at the club, who opted for another former Chelsea man in the form of Gus Poyet, as he was announced as manager last year.

Ferguson spotted Ben Foster while he was playing for Wrexham in the Football League Trophy final and snapped him up for United for £1m in July 2005. However, his stay in Manchester was short-lived as he was loaned out to Watford to gain some much-needed experience.

He spent two years at Vicarage Road, making 81 appearances before returning to his parent club in summer 2007. A cruciate ligament injury sidelined him for about six months, but Foster finally made his United debut in March 2008.

Sadly, he didn't play another first-team game for the rest of the season. After featuring in a total of 23 games for the club and even winning the League Cup with United twice, Foster moved to Birmingham City on a permanent deal in 2010.
Since retiring from the game after a short spell with Wrexham, the 42-year-old has put plenty of effort and time into his popular podcast, Fozcast.

Nemanja Vidic joined the Red Devils in January 2006 in a £7m deal from Spartak Moscow. Ferguson threw him straight into the mix, with his debut coming in a League Cup semi-final second-leg match against Blackburn.

The centre-back had a rocky start, in and out of the team for his first six months, before forming a formidable partnership with Rio Ferdinand ahead of the 2006/07 season. This duo has since been hailed as one of football's most iconic pairings.

Vidic played a key role in United's Champions League victory in 2008, and also bagged five Premier League titles during his tenure at the club. After making 300 appearances for the Red Devils, Vidic bid farewell to United at the end of the 2013/14 season, having netted 21 goals – an impressive tally for a central defender.

After leaving United, 18 months on the books at Inter Milan followed, before he hung up his boots for good following a string of injury problems that eventually saw his contract terminated by mutual consent.
Torn between Inter Milan and United, Patrice Evra eventually chose a move to England for £5.5m in January 2006. However, the French full-back initially struggled to adapt to the English game.

Despite early hiccups, Evra managed to iron out his mistakes and became a vital part of the United squad, ending his first season with 14 appearances under his belt. Although he wasn't a regular starter in the 2007/08 season, he still contributed significantly to United's Premier League title win and soon became a mainstay in the team.

headline: Why is Man Utd vs West Ham not on UK TV? How to watch Premier League action
body: Manchester United may be fresh off reaching the Europa League final, but they now turn their attention to the Premier League as they face West Ham. The Red Devils have received quite the reprieve from their European adventure this season.

Despite Ruben Amorim's arrival, the club have struggled on the domestic front with United without a win since beating the now relegated Leicester City 3-0 in mid March. Graham Potters' Hammers aren't faring much better.

The Irons have been struggling and haven't won in the league since they also defeated the Foxes 2-0, all the way back in February. West Ham did hand United one of their 16 losses this season however, when they two met at the London Stadium in October.

Then managed by Julen Lopetegui, Crysencio Summerville and a late Jarrod Bowen penalty earned West Ham a 2-1 win over a United side then overseen by Erik ten Hag. The Dutchman subsequently received his marching orders after the defeat, making way for Amorim.

With United's continued success in the Europa League, their clash against West Ham was moved to Sunday. Amorim's side played Athletic Bilbao on Thursday evening, booking their place in the final with a 4-1 win on the night, and a 7-1 win on aggregate.
Starting next season this will change as all matches not scheduled for a 3pm kick-off on Saturday will be broadcast live in the UK due to the Premier League's new TV deal.
While Arsenal, fresh off their Champions League semi-final disappointment, will head to Anfield to take on Premier League champions Liverpool.
That game kicks-off at 16:30 with all eyes expected to be on Mikel Arteta's and his team's guard of honour for Arne Slot's triumphant side.

headline: Man Utd's likely starting lineup for West Ham fixture with nine changes set to be made
body: Ruben Amorim will rotate his Manchester United team again for Sunday's Premier League game against West Ham at Old Trafford - with all eyes on the Europa League final against Tottenham Hotspur in less than a fortnight's time.

And while the United head coach has warned his top players that they will need to be sharp for the season-defining showdown in Bilbao on May 21, he is expected to rest several following their midweek semi-final win against Athletic Club. That is despite a much-changed team failing to keep things tight defensively away to Brentford last weekend, where they lost 4-3 for a club record 16th defeat of their league season.
Skipper Bruno Fernandes , defenders Harry Maguire and Noussair Mazraoui, midfielder Casemiro and winger Alejandro Garnacho will all be taken out of Sunday's starting line-up.
But they will likely come back into the team for next Friday’s trip to Chelsea after Amorim recognised that they cannot afford to go into such a huge game against Spurs without match sharpness.

“No, they will play, because sometimes it's better to play,” said Amorim. “What I will protect is those players who can get an injury. The last game before Tottenham, away to Chelsea, was moved to Friday, so we will have time to recover.
“Bruno doesn't have the problem of any injury, but Harry has, so we will have to manage that. But they have to play and it's better to play than to stay out.
“With some players, we have some doubts that they will recover, but they will push forward a little bit. We have to manage that, not to take risks and then to have big issues.
"Of course, they will fight for a place in the final. They will be ready, excited.
“That's a good thing, not just for the final, but also to prepare for the games of the Premier League, with something in our minds that we can win. It's going to be massive.
“I think it's a good thing for the players that we will not have a lot of training sessions. They will fight for their places in the final in these next two games.
"Against Brentford, we made some mistakes and I felt that some of our players were thinking about this game [against Bilbao].”

Victor Lindelof and Manuel Ugarte may be the only players to retain their starting spot from Thursday night. Altay Bayindir is expected to replace Andre Onana between the posts against the Hammers, while Tyler Fredricson and Luke Shaw could start at the back in place of Maguire and Leny Yoro.
Christian Eriksen and youngster Harry Amass could come into the midfield and Chido Obi expected to start up front, Mason Mount could also be in the starting XI.
Possible Man Utd team to face West Ham (3-4-2-1): Bayindir; Fredricson, Lindelof, Shaw; Amad, Eriksen, Ugarte, Amass; Mainoo, Mount; Chido.

headline: Man Utd youngster's transfer left manager calling for probe over 'blatant manipulation'
body: Of the 17 players to have played for both Crystal Palace and Tottenham Hotspur in the Premier League era, Zeki Fryers is among the more likely who would go down as a Pointless answer.
But the left back was once part of a controversial transfer that left Sir Alex Ferguson fuming and calling for a Football Association investigation into what he claimed was “blatant manipulation.”

Fryers had left United for Belgian club Standard Liege in August 2012 for a small compensation fee after Spurs refused to pay £6m. Except by the following January Spurs had paid Standard £3m for Fryers, who claimed he was feeling homesick.

"I'm disappointed in Tottenham. I think it's a blatant manipulation of the situation," Ferguson said not long after the transfer to north London went through. "I think the league should look into it and I think they should stop his registration until they examine it."
Tottenham claimed afterwards that they only made a second approach for Fryers after being made aware that he was not enjoying life in Belgium.

A Spurs spokesman said at the time: "Zeki enjoyed his time at Standard, however, when Standard sacked their manager in November Zeki wasn't part of the new manager's plans which he accepts and understands happens in football. Unfortunately, a combination of this and the fact he had become homesick meant he wanted to return to England.

"His representatives made contact with clubs in England. This afforded us a second opportunity to sign the player and as per Fifa's solidarity contribution mechanism, Manchester United will receive 5 per cent of the transfer fee we have paid."

Standard Liege later issued a statement which read: "The young defender felt homesick and had difficulty acclimating to life away from home and family. So when the London club became interested we understood the situation and were not opposed to the return of the player in England."

But fuming Ferguson added: "They tried to buy him from us at the end of last season. They then took him on trial and said they couldn't afford him and all of a sudden he signed for Standard Liege. I expected him to go to Tottenham in the January transfer window. The league should look into it."
Fryers, who was most recently playing in the Swedish third tier, went on to make 16 appearances in 18 months at Spurs before moving to Palace, for whom he made 14 appearances.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund breaks silence on nightmare season and hails 'wonderful' Man Utd star
body: Rasmus Hojlund believes he is finally starting to emerge from his Manchester United nightmare to prove he can be worth £72million. The 22-year-old Danish striker has never hidden behind excuses after scoring just 11 goals for Ruben Amorim’s struggling team this season.

But the smile was back on Old Trafford faces after he got on the scoresheet as United booked a Europa League date with Tottenham with a 7-1 aggregate hammering of Athletic Bilbao. However, Hojlund still admits it's been a disappointing campaign for the Reds.

He said: “We’re very happy about being in the final, but it can’t take away the focus from the entire season. Domestically it has not been good enough - but then again we play to win trophies and we are in a good position to win a European one.

“I think we’ve been improving in the last few weeks, even though the results in the Premier League have not been overly good, just in Europe. But in the Premier League we are gradually getting there - although we know we need to get better.
“Obviously there have been hard times for me. When you go without a goal for a lot of games - I wouldn’t say I lost self-belief, but you’re going to be a bit more down and a bit more frustrated.
“It’s been about going back to basics and focusing on what I can do to try and improve myself. I will check myself, chat with my team-mates, get in better positions…these sorts of things.

“It is the hard times that make you better and you learn a lot from them. I have always said I know what this football club is all about and it’s a lot of pressure, but that is why I’m here. I want to show myself on the biggest stage.
“We are focusing on the opportunity we have here. That can give us something from this year to take into the next season - because winning a trophy is always important for a club this size.”

United now face West Ham at Old Trafford as they attempt to improve their poor Premier League position in the last three games of the season. Amorim has been boosted by the return to action of Amad Diallo, the young winger who has been sidelined for three months with an ankle injury.

Amad produced a stunning cameo performance against Bilbao on Thursday night - and Hojlund said: “Amad is wonderful. I obviously knew him a bit before I came here because we played at Atalanta. Not at the same time, but they talked of him. He’s a great talent, what a player.
“He came through the Atalanta academy. He’s a very good lad, very humble and down to earth. That’s why he is where he is now.

“Last season he didn’t really have a lot of game-time but now he has shown himself and he is so calm and focused on improving. We know his qualities and this season they have been shining through. Full credit to him.”

headline: Man Utd hold transfer upper hand in two-club battle for summer free agent
body: Manchester United are ready to battle with Bayern Munich for the services of Jonathan Tah. The Bayer Leverkusen defender will be a free agent this summer and won't be short of offers.
United have held talks with Tah's agent Pini Zahavi about a move to the Premier League and are confident of landing the 29-year-old, who tasted Bundesliga success with Leverkusen last season.

Bayern, as has been the case for decades, have often looked to land their rivals' top talent and they now want to sign Tah when his time at the BayArena ends. They seem him as a replacement for Eric Dier, who will leave for Monaco this summer.

Tah is flattered by Bayern's interest, reports the Daily Star, but has had a long-standing ambition to play in England's top flight with the Manchester outfit ready to grant him that opportunity as Ruben Amorim looks to bolster the options in his backline.

The German defender is willing to ramp up negotiations with the Red Devils if they land a spot in next season's Champions League, which would need them to beat Tottenham in the Europa League final later this month.

Qualifying for the Champions League would bank United an extra £100million and transform their summer transfer plans. Amorim will need a huge window if he is to turn around the team's fortunes and has concerns over the long-term fitness of Lisandro Martinez, who is again sidelined.

Last summer United spent big to land Leny Yoro from Lille. The defender was highly though of in France and, after originally being sidelined through injury, has shown in glimpses that he can be hugely effective in the backline.

It has also been reported that Newcastle hold an interest in Tah with the Magpies looking to add more quality to their squad. Like United, their summer plans are dependent on qualifying for the Champions League, but they are in a strong position in the league.

Leverkusen are set for a summer of mass change. Tah's exit is imminent and Xabi Alonso has announced that he will depart following some stunning achievements with Real Madrid seen as his most likely destination. Attacking star Florian Wirtz is of interest to Manchester City.

headline: Old foe to give Jadon Sancho transfer lifeline as Chelsea prepare to pay £5m penalty
body: Manchester United misfit Jadon Sancho is set to be offered a lifeline by Bayer Leverkusen with Chelsea ready to pay a £5million penalty for pulling out of a £25million obligation to buy the winger at the end of the season.

United are ready to cut their losses on the £73million former England international after discovering that the London club are now unlikely to take up the option of signing Sancho permanently following his season-long loan at Stamford Bridge. That has alerted Bundesliga pair Bayer Leverkusen and Borussia Dortmund.

Both would want Sancho to take a cut on his current £250,000-a-week salary - but United are hoping that their willingness to accept less than £20million for the 25-year-old will make the numbers work. And Leverkusen are now looking to add some creativity to their squad as they prepare for life without coach Xabi Alonso and playmaker Florian Wirtz.
Alonso is set to replace Carlo Ancelotti at Real Madrid, while Wirtz is the £100million-plus talent wanted by both Manchester City and Bayern Munich.
Leverkusen could use some of that cash to beat Dortmund to Sancho - and will also be able to offer him Champions League football while their rivals are struggling to finish in the top four.
Sancho enjoyed the best spell of his career at Dortmund before moving to Old Trafford four years ago and returned for a loan spell when things went sour at United.
United boss Ruben Amorim has made it clear there is no way back for Sancho, Marcus Rashford or Antony - and the Reds are trying to find solutions to raise money for a squad rebuild.

Sancho will have just one year left on his contract in the summer and his valuation will continue to tumble once Chelsea confirm their intention to trigger a clause which will enable them to drop any obligation to buy by paying United £5million in compensation.

headline: Erik ten Hag closes in on first job since Man Utd exit but Arsenal icon poses issue
body: Former Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag is closing in on his next job after reportedly being in the running to become the next Bayer Leverkusen manager, though he is said to be "neck and neck" with ex-Arsenal star Cesc Fabregas. Ten Hag has not coached since being axed by the Red Devils in October after guiding the team to their worst start in Premier League history this season.
His successor Ruben Amorim has been unable to galvanise the team since replacing the Dutchman, though he has led them to a Europa League final against Tottenham on May 21.
Ten Hag has been linked with a number of roles since leaving United but is still waiting for his return to the dugout but could stand to profit from Xabi Alonso's departure from the Bundesliga side.
Alonso announced he would be leaving the club on Friday after guiding them to the Bundesliga and German Cup last season, with the Spaniard widely expected to replace Carlo Ancelotti at Real Madrid.

Leverkusen will want to continue the excellent work Alonso has done and German outlet Kicker claim that the club have narrowed down their search to either Ten Hag or Fabregas - who currently manages Serie A side Como.

Ten Hag endured plenty of criticism during his two years at United after overseeing some woeful displays and inconsistency, but his CV remains impressive with two cup wins during his time at Old Trafford - on top of five trophies at Ajax.
But Leverkusen may feel Fabregas is the more promising up-and-coming coach following impressive work at Como, helping them to 10th in the table after earning promotion last season.
The report adds that Erik ten Hag would demand a higher wage package than Fabregas - though the Spaniard would cost more to hire because the German outlet would have to pay Como compensation.
It's believed Leverkusen would have to stump up around £10m to release him from his contract, which runs until 2028.
Whoever does replace Alonso will have big shoes to fill after he won the team their first Bundesliga title in their 119-year history, while also lifting the German Cup in the same system.

Announcing his departure on Friday, Alonso said: "This week, the club and I have agreed these will be my last two games as Leverkusen coach. This is the right moment to announce it because we have always had this good communication with the club.

'We have to enjoy this moment with mixed emotions, it is emotional! I spoke to the players and the staff it was not easy. We've had a great connection and that's been the key. They believed in me and they've followed me. I want to have a proper goodbye this weekend.'

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe's brutal Europa League Final decision sparks anger at Man Utd
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has opted against handing free Europa League final tickets to Manchester United staff members as his brutal cost-cutting continues. The Red Devils will contest the showpiece event in Bilbao - but their employees won't be rewarded with complimentary tickets - which is in stark contrast to the decisions taken by Tottenham

United will take on the north Londoners in an all-Premier League affair and they have been given an allocation of around 15,000 for the clash on May 21. The Manchester club are holding a ballot where a small number of tickets will be available for their staff. They have chosen to host a screening for the majority of staff closer to home with the invite open to plus-ones.

Ratcliffe's frugal nature means that the member of staff will be given two free drinks, while their guests will have to pay for theirs, reports the Daily Mail. Tottenham meanwhile have chosen to offer a complimentary ticket to every full-time employee should they want to travel to Bilbao - which could be up to 700 individuals.

Those within Old Trafford feel that the club are prioritising supporters over staff, with tickets naturally in high demand. It is the Red Devils first European final since 2021, when they lost the Europa League final. On that occasion they had just 2,000 tickets as the world was emerging from the Covid lockdown.
In the past, whilst they had significantly higher allocations, United paid for flights, accommodation and food for staff for the last three Champions League finals the club have appeared in.

For the Europa League final in 2017 the club had an allocation of just 10,000. As a result they planned an event in Manchester at which drinks would have been free, with former Take That singer Gary Barlow due to provide entertainment. The event was later cancelled after the Manchester Arena terror attack.

Ratcliffe and Ineos, since taking charge in Manchester, have overseen two rounds of redundancies as the billionaire seeks to cut costs and redirect revenue towards the playing squad. Staff have seen a number of benefits taken away from them, which includes the cancelling of the Christmas party.

Ratcliffe's stance could not differ more from PSG president Nasser Al-Khelaifi, who will pay for the 600 staff members at the Parisian outfit to go to the Champions League final. All club employees will be able to attend the Champions League final on May 31 against Inter Milan as the French side look to conquer Europe for the first time.
Both sides received around 19,000 tickets for the match and it also been reported that Inter Milan are providing free tickets to their staff for the clash at the Allianz Arena in Munich.

headline: Bruno Fernandes already has Man Utd exit plan in place ahead of new Al-Hilal meeting
body: Manchester United captain Bruno Fernandes has already made it clear he wants to play in Brazil before he retires as Saudi Arabian outfit Al Hilal continue their attempts to lure the playmaker to the Middle East. Fernandes has been the saviour of United's turbulent season with 19 goals in all competitions and 15 assists, helping the team reach the Europa League final against Tottenham.
But the Portugal international has also been linked with an exit from Old Trafford as he prepares to enter the final two years of his contract, with Al Hilal pushing for a move.

Saudi Pro League president Fahad bin Nafel is understood to have met with Fernandes' agent Miguel Ruben and lawyer Caetano Maria on Monday to present a lucrative three-year deal - though that proposal was rejected by his inner circle.
United are not planning to sell Fernandes and see him as crucial to their future plans, with the midfielder committed to the club for the duration of his contract.

However, the player has confirmed he does intend to leave United one day and sees himself playing in the Brazilian league because the football is "attractive and electric" and says he watches it when he can.
He said: "Whenever I can, I follow it, because I find Brazilian football attractive, electric football, with a lot of quality, joy, very one-on-one.
"It’s pure football. And I think that now, with the coaches that are there, not only the Portuguese, but also Brazilians, are increasingly developing in the tactical part.

"I don’t really like talking about the distant future, but it’s like I said. It’s attractive football, very interesting. The only thing is that the trips are very long there in Brazil! There are many competitions, many clubs that play Libertadores and Sudamericana, very good competitions. I’m not saying no, because Brazilian football is very attractive, and we never know the future."
For now, Fernandes will be totally focused on United's huge upcoming Europa League final, which will come against Premier League rivals Tottenham in Bilbao on May 21.

Amorim has previously insisted the club want to keep Fernandes and won't entertain any bids. He said: "Our idea didn't change. We want to keep the best players - and Bruno is clearly one of the top players in the world. We want Bruno here.

"It is easy to understand [his importance] - not just because of the numbers but the way he plays and the importance he has during his five years here. It's normal that a lot of clubs want a player like Bruno. He is a leader and he's the captain, so he's really important. He is a top player, we need top players."

headline: Chelsea sent Jadon Sancho transfer message as ex-star learns of contract clause
body: Florent Malouda has urged Chelsea to swerve a permanent deal for Jadon Sancho. The Blues can keep the winger, who has mustered four goals and 10 assists in all competitions this season, for £25million or alternatively, pay a £5m penalty clause to send him back to Manchester United.

However, ex-Chelsea and France star Malouda is sceptical about a deal due to Sancho's inconsistent form. He told Racing Tipster: "I didn't see what I was expecting from him after he joined on loan from Manchester United.
"For Jadon Sancho, it's not about his talent anymore. The point is more we haven't really seen Sancho showing that he really wants to succeed on the pitch with Chelsea.
"So at this point I don't think it would be a good thing for him to stay at Chelsea, because I guess that the club will try to sign new players, so he will probably go back to Manchester United."
Chelsea have now booked their ticket to Wroclaw for the UEFA Conference League final after successfully seeing off Swedish outfit Djurgardens.

Enzo Maresca's side also remain in control of their own destiny in the Premier League's nerve-jangling race for a top-five finish following last weekend's 3-1 victory over Liverpool. But even if the Blues fall short domestically, Malouda believes Chelsea's season should be considered a success if they pick up European silverware.

He continued: "Yes [season would still be successful], because that would be a first title, a first trophy for this group of players under Enzo Maresca. The only way for me to assess a good season for Chelsea, or any club, is how many trophies you win at the end of the season.
"A win isn’t just about the trophy either, a Conference League win will give the players and fans hope and confidence in the project.

"With all that at stake for the club, and the manager, I think there's a lot of pressure and I think it is a must-win for the club, and that it will be a successful season even if they don’t get Champions League football."
Cole Palmer also netted his first goal in 18 matches against Arne Slot's Premier League champions. Malouda feels there has been too much pressure on the attacker's shoulders of late.
He concluded: "His first goal after a while was good for his confidence. There’s so much expectation on him and he is the key player, so it's very demanding physically and mentally.

"I think this is where he needs to find the right balance. You need to see him enjoying his game, and I think that's where you can get the edge, and make sure that you perform in the top games and make the difference."

headline: New Bruno Fernandes transfer meeting plotted as Man Utd statement ignored
body: Al Hilal are refusing to give up on an eye-watering transfer deal for Bruno Fernandes - as club chiefs officials line up a third meeting with his representatives. Fahad bin Nafel, who is the president of the Saudi Pro League club, is understood to have met with Bruno Fernandes' agent Miguel Ruben and lawyer Caetano Maria on Monday.
During those discussions, Al Hilal presented a lucrative three-year contract offer for the Manchester United captain but the proposal was politely rejected by Fernandes' inner circle.

United are not willing to entertain a sale and insist the Portugal international is integral to their plans - a stance publicly communicated by Ruben Amorim in recent days - and equally, the 30-year-old remains committed to his Old Trafford contract which runs until the summer of 2027.
However, Saudi sources have indicated that Al Hilal are yet to concede defeat and they're planning a third sit-down with Fernandes' camp.
The first meeting between the parties is understood to have taken place in London but financials were not discussed.

Now Al Hilal are keen to launch one final push, they believe a third round of discussions are on the agenda and they are willing to show notable flexibility on potential salary demands in a bid to turn the player's head.

Newcastle captain Bruno Guimaraes and Aston Villa star Youri Tielemans have also attracted admirers at Al Hilal and could emerge as alternative targets if a deal for Fernandes proves out of reach. Al Hilal's interest in Fernandes is long-standing and their previous advances for his services were swiftly shot down in 2023 and 2024.
The Saudi giants would like to bolster their squad with an array of superstar signings for the Club World Cup ahead of their Group H opener against Real Madrid on June 18.

Fernandes has 19 goals and 19 assists in all competitions this season and Manchester United's summer transfer budget is expected to be dictated by the result of their Europa League final against Tottenham.

Amorim said ahead of their 4-1 semi-final victory over Athletic Club: "Our idea didn't change. We want to keep the best players - and Bruno is clearly one of the top players in the world. We want Bruno here.

"It is easy to understand [his importance] - not just because of the numbers but the way he plays and the importance he has during his five years here. It's normal that a lot of clubs want a player like Bruno. He is a leader and he's the captain, so he's really important. He is a top player, we need top players."

Fernandes wants to win silverware at United and it's clear the team is on an upwards trajectory under Amorim with an series of big-name signings planned - Matheus Cunha, Viktor Gyokeres, Liam Delap, Jonathan Tah and Bryan Mbeumo are among their targets - in the upcoming months.

headline: Paul Scholes names Man Utd star Ruben Amorim must refuse to sell in summer overhaul
body: Paul Scholes insists Manchester United have to retain Bruno Fernandes amid talk of interest from Saudi Arabia. In what has been a dire season the Portuguese playmaker has been a shining light.

United are open to selling almost every player on their books as Ruben Amorim looks to lead a much needed overhaul. Even academy star Kobbie Mainoo could be moved on should the club receive an offer they deem suitable.

Fernandes is perhaps their most prized asset and would command the greatest fee in the market, but Scholes is adamant he must be retained at any cost, despite the riches than could be waved United's way from Saudi Arabia. They have spare cash after missing out on Mohamed Salah.

United's skipper has scored 19 times in all competitions - his highest number since his first full season - and continues to produce in the big moments. Scholes has claimed that Fernandes has to be the player the club build their team around.

"It’s quite clear that they need to keep him and build a team around him. It’s just whether they get the option to do that with having money to buy new players and adding space in the squad to bring new players in.

"With the deals that the club have done in the last few years, it’s going to be very difficult for Amorim to get rid of people. If you get into the Champions League, it’s going to be quite easy to bring people in, but at the same time, you’ve got to get people out and that’s going to be the hardest part of his job."

Amorim has maintained that United want to retain Fernandes and will not be allowing him to leave this summer. “I think it is easy to understand [his importance], not just because of the numbers but the way he plays, the importance that he has during his five years here,” he said.

“He is a top player, we need top players. He is a leader, he’s the captain, so he’s really important. It’s normal that a lot of clubs want a player like Bruno, like [Alejandro] Garnacho, like others, but we want to keep the best players, and Bruno is clearly one of the top players in the world, so our idea didn’t change. We want Bruno here.”

headline: Paul Scholes fumes at Ruben Amorim over Manchester United plan - 'I don't like it'
body: Former Manchester United star Paul Scholes isn't a fan of Ruben Amorim's approach of playing a weakened side for Premier League matches while chasing European glory. Amorim made major changes to the starting XI for last week's defeat at Brentford, including leaving captain Bruno Fernandes on the bench, in order to keep players fresh to face Athletic Club on Thursday.

United lost 4-3 at the Gtech and then fell behind early on in their Europa League semi-final second leg. They rebounded in style, though, scoring four times in the final 20 minutes to wrap up a 7-1 aggregate victory, but Scholes believes his old employers are taking a big risk.
"It’s almost as if they go into Premier League games and there’s an acceptance that they’re not going to win the game, which is madness. I think the acceptance has come from everyone.

"I think it’s come from the manager even though he won’t admit it. He’s not playing teams to win games of football in the league. I think even fans are thinking let’s get these league games out of the way because the league has been a disaster."

United aren't the only ones who have attempted to shuffle the pack in the league while competing in Europe. It didn't quite work for Arsenal, who lost their Champions League semi-final against Paris Saint-Germain, but Spurs' rotation at West Ham last week left them fresh to beat Bodo/Glimt and join Amorim's team in the Europa League final.

Ahead of Sunday's match, Amorim was asked whether he would continue resting senior stars now that a spot in the final has been secured. "No, they will play because sometimes it's better to play," he replied.
"What I will protect is the players that can get an injury. For example, Bruno, or the last game before Tottenham but we moved the game to the Friday against Chelsea. So we'll have time to recover.

"We want to win and to be competitive, also in the Premier League. Bruno doesn't have the problem of any injury [touches wood] but Harry [Maguire] has. So we have to manage that but they have to play and it is better to play than to stay out."

headline: Roy Keane’s stroke of genius saw him make healthy profit from Glazers' Man Utd deal
body: Former Manchester United captain Roy Keane once admitted that he financially benefited from the Glazer family's takeover of the club. The American ownership has been a contentious issue among fans since they acquired the club 20 years ago.

Writing in his 2014 autobiography, The Second Half, Keane revealed his smart idea to pocket shares in United as part of his contract, meaning he saw a small fortune head his way thanks to the family's acquisition of the Red Devils.
"From the players’ point of view, it didn’t bother us too much," Keane, 53, wrote. "I had a few shares in the club as part of my contract. So the Glazers coming in was worth a few bob to me".

The Glazers are now approaching two decades at the helm of United, having acquired the club from Irish shareholders John Magnier and JP McManus for £790million on May 12, 2005. Initially holding a 57 per cent stake, they increased it to 75 per cent just days later.

Despite the team's early successes under their ownership, including five Premier League titles, the 2008 Champions League, two FA Cups, six League Cups, the Europa League, and the FIFA World Club Cup, fans have expressed concerns about the Glazers draining the club's resources.
Their tenure has been marred by fan protests and widespread dissatisfaction with their management of the club. And the situation reached a head in 2022.

Their reign at the helm of United seemed on the brink in November of that year when they announced the club was up for sale. Keane hailed the move as "good news" at the time, criticising the family for prioritising business over their rapport with the supporters.

However, the plot took a twist when Sir Jim Ratcliffe instead acquired a minority 25 per cent share, leaving the Americans in post but with Ratcliffe and his INEOS team taking control of football operations. However, United's financial woes have persisted, with debts mounting and job cuts becoming a regularity under Ratcliffe's time in charge.

While Keane may have profited from the initial sale, he has since been vocal about his disapproval of United's current management. In October 2024, he lamented the transformation of the club on the Stick to Football podcast.
"United was always about good people and good characters, but I don't see that now. I don't recognise this team, I don't recognise the club," he said.

"They're chopping and changing and getting rid of everyone in the background which is fine, there's a business side to it, we know that. But when we're discussing Man United, it's more like a business than a football club".

headline: Manchester United vs West Ham LIVE score and goal updates
body: Manchester United will be hoping to build on Thursday night's 4-1 win over Athletic Bilbao when they welcome West Ham United to Old Trafford in the Premier League this afternoon, kick-off 2.15pm.

United booked their place in the Europa League final in midweek with an impressive victory over the Spanish outfit, with goals from Mason Mount (2), Rasmus Hojlund and Casemiro sealing a 7-1 aggregate triumph.
However, focus switches back to domestic matters this afternoon and a league tussle with a Hammers side also experiencing a forgettable Premier League campaign.
United head into the contest winless in their last six league outings and without a home win in the Premier League since the end of February.
Head coach Ruben Amorim had made changes for the visit of West Ham. Here's the United starting XI: Bayindir; Mazraoui, Yoro, Shaw; Amad, Ugarte, Mainoo, Amass; Fernandes, Mount; Hojlund.
Follow the LIVE blog below for regular updates and analysis from Old Trafford throughout the day.

Three minutes in and we have had the first rendition of Amorim's chant. There are few United players who are serenaded these days. Fernandes often is and he earned that acclaim long ago. It is rather telling that United fans cannot be bothered to add to their biblical songbook for some of the others.
Amad and Fernandes just combined smartly for a shot at goal but the latter could not keep it down.

Mainoo has started in the right hand side No.10 role. Mainoo and Amad are friends away from the pitch and their chemistry should help them link up down that right flank this afternoon. David Moyes is in the directors' box and the West Ham fans chanted his name before kick-off.
We are off and underway at Old Trafford!

Sir Dave Brailsford, one of the most redundant employees at United, is in the directors' box in the Ineos row with Omar Berrada and director of communications Toby Craig. Whatever United achieve, it will have nothing to do with a bloke who used to run a cycling team, regardless of how warmly he clasps hands with Diogo Dalot. If United win the Europa League, it’ll be down to Ruben Amorim, his staff and the players.
Both sets of players are starting to gather inside the tunnel ahead of kick-off.
Stay tuned to this LIVE blog for regular updates throughout the afternoon.

The directors' box is a lot sparser today, unsurprisingly. There is only a few million pounds riding on the game (which makes it sound important) and it is such a blissfully warm day many would rather do something else. That said, the majority of the regulars sat around the press box are here today to justify the expense of their season tickets.
The countdown to kick-off at Old Trafford is very nearly over. Stay tuned to this LIVE blog for regular updates throughout the afternoon.

Leny Yoro will be playing between Noussair Mazraoui and Luke Shaw in the back three. Yoro has been on the left recently but will shift inside to accommodate Shaw. The trio are just warming up in order at the moment.

This already has an end-of-season feel to it, mostly because of the gorgeous weather. The players are just finishing their warm ups and should return to the dressing room to prepare for kick-off in a moment.
Head coach Ruben Amorim has explained why he has made six changes to his starting XI for this afternoon's clash with West Ham.
The United boss, as expected, has shuffled his pack for today's game, but the starting line-up is much stronger than almost all of us anticipated.
On the changes, Amorim told MUTV:

"First of all we want to win the game and perform, it's really important for us. Of course, we are going to save some players that could have the risk of some injury, even if it's a small thing, we are so near a big goal for our season. But we need to win, to perform, and we have players to do that today."
Click here to read more.
United's clash with West Ham is one of five Premier League games taking place today, with the first kicking off at 12pm.
That clash saw Newcastle United and Chelsea go head-to-head at St James' Park and Newcastle currently lead 1-0 with 20 minutes to go.
The rest of today's games see Nottingham Forest host Leicester City (2.15pm), Tottenham Hotspur face Crystal Palace (2.15pm) and Liverpool take on Arsenal at Anfield (4.30pm).

'Really looking forward to Aaron Wan-Bissaka's return'. Said no one. It only just occurred to yours truly that he is making his return to United today. In keeping with the man's character, it is a low-key return.

Someone just said he is one of West Ham's player of the year contenders. He did quite well in the reverse fixture and actually scored, never mind attacked, against Newcastle in the first half of the season.
He did well to have five years at United and win two trophies. He was very good in the FA Cup final, his last appearance for the club.

The assumption is that Kobbie Mainoo will start in one of the No.10 roles, with Bruno Fernandes and Manuel Ugarte in the pivot, but the Stockport-born lad could start in the deeper role again. Everyone expected Mainoo to start as a No.10 against Bournemouth last month and he was given another chance in the deeper midfield role alongside Casemiro.
Having deservedly bagged a start after scoring twice via the bench against Athletic Bilbao on Thursday night, Mason Mount will be looking to score for the third game running this afternoon.
He scored as a starter at Brentford last weekend and scored two superb goals late on in midweek after coming off the bench.
He has more goals in the past week (three) than he had previously got in the whole of his United career (one).

United have three wins in their last ten and they were all in the Europa League. They have not won a Premier League match since the domestic season restarted after the March internationals. That last league win at Leicester was nearly two months ago on March 16.

If United lose again today, they will still embark on a half-lap of honour and get clapped. The support I can understand. The half-lap of honour I can't. And the happy-clappy reactions are sometimes unbecoming for the club's worst domestic side in 51 years.

There was much more rancour over defeats (City at home and Bournemouth at home) and decisions (substituting Rasmus Hojlund against Brighton and Kobbie Mainoo against Burnley) last season. United supporters are now completely accepting of how bad the team is. And so are people at the club, which is why this season has been a strangely calm one to cover.
A couple of confirmations from Ruben Amorim's latest selection: Christian Eriksen is not deemed up to it in this system and his compatriot, Chido Obi, is not ready to start competitive matches.
Eriksen will be gone by the end of next month. Obi has potential but cannot be one of the two first-team squad strikers next season.

That's a much stronger team than probably everyone expected to see this afternoon. Rasmus Hojlund is the only senior striker who is fit in the dressing room and retains his starting role. That could be seen as a risk ahead of the Europa League final.
Former United right-back Aaron Wan-Bissaka has been included in the West Ham starting XI this afternoon.
Your starting XI in Manchester pic.twitter.com/DzxOIft7Af

Looking at that United side, you wonder whether the team against Chelsea will be weaker now. Ruben Amorim was fretting over Noussair Mazraoui in midweek but is starting him today and his inclusion in a back three, as well as Amad on the right wing, feels significant. Those two should be starting in those roles in the final.
United starting XI vs West Ham United: Bayindir; Mazraoui, Yoro, Shaw; Amad, Ugarte, Mainoo, Amass; Fernandes, Mount; Hojlund.
Substitutes: Heaton, Fredricson, Lindelof, Maguire, Dorgu, Eriksen, Casemiro, Garnacho, Obi.
The all-important team news from Old Trafford will be confirmed at 1pm, meaning we will soon be able to bring you details of how United will line-up this afternoon.
The expectation is that head coach Ruben Amorim will ring the changes following Thursday night's 4-1 win over Athletic Bilbao in the Europa League.
After making an impressive impact off the bench in midweek, Amad will be desperate to get his first start since overcoming his ankle injury this afternoon.
He should start the Europa League final in just over a week's time and he needs to improve his match sharpness ahead of it.

West Ham haven't won a game for almost three months. They last won against Leicester City on February 27. They've been horrendous in the Premier League this season and haven't made any progress since Graham Potter's appointment.

They've only maintained their top flight status because there are three worse teams, and United should be confident of winning this afternoon, even with a much-changed starting side. West Ham are without a league victory for eight fixtures now and the last time they recorded a longer winless run in the Premier League was between March and May 2011 (they were relegated). That is awful.
Courtesy of Betfair, here are the pre-match odds ahead of today's game at Old Trafford:

The 'keeper was not spotted arriving alongside his teammates this morning. Altay Bayindir is expected to start in goal with Tom Heaton on the bench. Dermot Mee will assist in the warm-ups with goalkeeping coach Jorge Vital.
Read why Onana is missing from today's squad here >>>

We've rarely seen Ruben Amorim smile this season, but there was a wide grin etched across his face when Mason Mount came off the bench to score twice on Thursday night. Mount's first goal was brilliantly taken and the technique for the halfway line goal was tremendous.

Mount's time in Manchester has been stop-start due to a few muscle injuries, but he has continued to do everything right away from the pitch and deserves the rub of the green going forward. Hopefully his display against Athletic Bilbao will ignite his time at the club.

It feels like Chido Obi will make his first start at Old Trafford. The young striker started against Brentford at the Gtech Stadium last weekend. He worked hard and put himself about, but his inexperience was obvious, and Amorim said:

"Chido fought all game but you can feel he's really naive sometimes in the way he puts his body. He's going to understand what is the feeling of playing in these kind of games, this is the best way. So we can take that positive, the rest we didn’t win points so just that."
Obi only celebrated his 17th birthday in November and he still has a long way to go.

The Europa League final is 10 days away and Ruben Amorim will spend each of those days preparing for the most important game of the season. Fixtures against West Ham and Chelsea in the Premier League are sandwiched in between.

There will be several changes to the starting line-up this afternoon and perhaps we will see a first-team debut handed out. Tyler Fredricson, Chido Obi and Harry Amass have done well since their promotion to the senior squad.
Andre Onana has been rested for today's game. Altay Bayindir's post all but confirms he will be starting, with Tom Heaton on the bench.

This has been such a dismal Premier League season the 'Champions League qualifying race' is not even engaging, despite the best efforts of some punters. City had a humiliating draw at Southampton and will still sleepwalk to a top five finish.

Finishing fifth and getting into the Champions League is far worse than winning the Europa League and getting into the competition. Jose Mourinho (of course) made a similar point of United's triumph in 2017. In his case, he deliberately tossed off the league and United finished a comfortable sixth. They could be ten places worse off this season.
Hopefully, for our sake, there is so little to play for between United and West Ham that both teams go hammer-and-tong for a win. One doubts it, though.

headline: LUCKHURST: Why Andre Onana isn't in Manchester United squad vs West Ham
body: Andre Onana has been rested for Manchester United's Premier League fixture against West Ham United.
Onana, who travelled to Brentford for last week's 4-3 defeat but was not in the squad, will sit out United's penultimate home fixture.
The 29-year-old is set to start the Europa League final against Tottenham Hotspur on May 21. Onana is likely to play in United's final match before the final at Chelsea next Friday.
United coach Ruben Amorim rested Onana for the 4-1 humbling by Newcastle United last month after he made two errors in the 2-2 Europa League quarter-final first leg against Lyon.
Altay Bayindir is expected to start in goal for the second league game running, despite conceding eight goals in his two league appearances for United.
Third-choice goalie Tom Heaton is expected to be on the bench again while academy 'keeper Dermot Mee will assist in the warm-ups with goalkeeping coach Jorge Vital.
Amorim has otherwise named a strong squad. Noussair Mazraoui did not travel to Brentford last week but he arrived at Old Trafford on Sunday morning.

headline: Ruben Amorim explains Manchester United changes vs West Ham as he opens up on 'risk'
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim has outlined his thinking behind his decision to make six changes to his starting line-up for this afternoon's Premier League clash with West Ham United.
It was widely anticipated that Amorim would make wholesale changes from the team that started the Europa League semi-final second leg victory over Athletic Bilbao less than 72 hours ago.
However, despite making changes in some areas of the team, bringing in Altay Bayindir, Luke Shaw, Harry Amass, Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount and Amad, he has selected a stronger XI than most predicted.

But with the Europa League final in Bilbao a little over a week away, Amorim has hinted that he needs to maintain high standards and go in search of positive results in the build-up to the clash with Tottenham Hotspur.
Amorim told MUTV: "First of all, we want to win the game and to perform, it's really important for us.
"Of course, we are going to save some players that could have the risk of some injury, even if it's a small thing, we are so near a big goal for our season.
"But we need to win, to perform, and we have players to do that today."

Facing an out-of-form West Ham side this afternoon, United will be determined to record a first Premier League win since the March international break. Amorim is keen to see his side avoid conceding any cheap goals after shipping four at Brentford in their last league outing.
"It's really important," Amorim added, addressing the importance of his players maintaining their concentration.
"I felt in the last games in the Premier League, we had opportunities to win the game. We suffer some goals, sometimes because of us.

"And we need to be really, really focused, again, we need to have that feeling that we need to win every game, but we also have to understand with a lot of rotation, especially in the defence, sometimes it's hard without training to put everything on the same page.
"But again, we have a strong squad and we are going to fight for the game today."

headline: MARSHALL: What Rasmus Hojlund heard about Amad before Manchester United move speaks volumes
body: By the time Rasmus Hojlund joined Atalanta, Amad had been gone for 18 months. The teenager played just 64 minutes of professional football before being snapped up by Manchester United in a deal worth up to £37million, but in Bergamo, they hadn't forgotten what they had seen.

When Hojlund made the same journey in August 2023, joining United from Atalanta in a move worth up to £72million, he was excited to see the player he had heard so much about in action, but whose trajectory had stalled a little at Old Trafford. While Hojlund was making a big enough impression at Atalanta to catch the eye of United, Amad was getting back into form with an impressive loan spell at Sunderland.

His first start for United last season came only a year ago on Monday, but the last 12 months have seen him make a breathtaking breakthrough, from fringe first-teamer whose days looked to be numbered, to probably the most dynamic and exciting attacking talent in the squad.

There have been 20 goal contributions in 43 games during the last 12 months, despite spending three months on the sidelines with a recent ankle injury, and he has made an instant impact on his return to the side, turning Thursday's Europa League semi-final second leg on its head when he came off the bench.

He set up the third goal for Hojlund in the 4-1 win that secured a 7-1 aggregate success against Athletic Club. The Dane pointed to Amad in front of the Stretord End, and when he was asked about him after the match, his face lit up as he explained how people had Atalanta had still talked about his talent.

"He’s wonderful. I obviously knew him a bit before I came here because we played in the same club. Not at the same time, but they talked of him. They spoke of him very highly. He’s a great talent, what a player," he said.
"And he’s not only focusing on himself but also trying to find the right solution for the team. It’s great to have him back."
Amad's megawatt smile and his infectious enthusiasm have helped to lift the mood of this squad, and Hojlund's affection for a player the same age as him was clear.
The Ivorian has become an entertaining presence on social media and snapped a selfie as the players celebrated Hojlund's goal on Thursday night.
"He’s a very good lad, very humble and down to earth. That’s why he is where he is now," said Hojlund.

"Last season, he didn’t really have a lot of game time, but now he has shown himself, and he is so calm and focused on improving. We know his qualities and this season they have been shining through. Full credit to him."

Both Amad and Hojlund have had their difficult moments at United. Amad has suffered injuries that held him back and went through a disappointing loan spell at Rangers, while Hojlund has endured a lengthy goal drought in recent months.
But the goals are starting to flow again for the Dane, and he believes those dark days will only serve him well going forward.

"Absolutely right, it is the hard times that make you better and you learn a lot from them," he said. “I have always said I know what this football club is all about and it’s a lot of pressure, but that is why I’m here. I want to show myself on the biggest stage.
"Obviously, there have been hard times. When you go without a goal for a lot of games, I wouldn’t say I lost self-belief, but you’re going to be a bit more down and a bit more frustrated.
"Then it is about going back to basics and focusing on what I can do to try and improve myself – I will check myself, chat with my teammates, get in better positions…these sorts of things."

headline: SMITH: Manchester United could do something they have not done in 33 years vs West Ham
body: Manchester United will be eyeing a first Premier League home win since late-February when they welcome West Ham United to Old Trafford this afternoon.

United will go into the clash with the Hammers riding the crest of a wave after booking their place in the Europa League final on Thursday night with a 4-1 win over Athletic Bilbao. Goals from Mason Mount (2), Rasmus Hojlund and Casemiro sealed a 7-1 aggregate triumph.
But before head coach Ruben Amorim can give the final and Tottenham Hotspur his full attention, he must first navigate his and his side's way through Premier League clashes with West Ham and Chelsea.
Ahead of this afternoon's tussle with the Hammers, here are five things to look out for:
If last weekend's 4-3 defeat to Brentford at the Gtech Community Stadium is anything to go by, United's supporters should anticipate a flurry of changes at Old Trafford this afternoon.

Amorim made eight changes for the clash with the Bees from the 3-0 win over Athletic in the Basque Country less than 72 hours before, with only Patrick Dorgu, Manuel Ugarte and Alejandro Garnacho retaining their places.

The chances are Amorim will make a crop of alterations to the side that started the second leg of the semi-final triumph, meaning the likes of Luke Shaw, Harry Amass, Kobbie Mainoo, Christian Eriksen, Mount and Amad will all be targeting starting berths.

Youngsters Jaydan Kamason, who is still waiting to make his senior debut, and Chido Obi will also be vying for starting berths in what will be another Premier League game with very, very little riding on it. Obi made his full league debut last weekend.

Although United's Europa League form has given their supporters plenty to celebrate in the last few weeks, their Premier League form has done anything but. The Reds head into today's game winless in six in the league, losing four.

Of course, strong arguments will be put forward for United's league campaign long since petering out and full focus being applied to their Europa League campaign instead, but the players will still have the ambition of winning and sending their supporters home happy.

Without a win in the league since the March international break, United are in danger of going seven league games without a win for the first time since the inaugural Premier League season in 1992/93.

That seven-game winless run saw United draw five and lose two between September and November. They drew the first five games of that sequence before being beaten by Wimbledon and Aston Villa, both by a 1-0 scoreline.
They eventually got back on track with a 3-0 home win over Charlton Athletic.

With changes guaranteed, all eyes will go in search of Amad's name when the teamsheet drops 75 minutes before kick-off. The Ivorian changed the game after coming off the bench against Athletic in midweek and his performance was a reminder of how big a role he can play in United's future under Amorim.

The former Sunderland loanee's cameo appearance against the Spanish side was his third outing in a row via the bench since recovering from a recent ankle injury, meaning the next challenge for him is to bag a start.
One of United's stars of the season, he must start the Europa League final, meaning it is important he builds up his match sharpness ahead of the trip to Spain in just over a week's time.

With no midweek fixture to think about this coming week, Amorim will be tempted to unleash Amad from the off. However, it will be interesting to see if he starts at wing-back or as the right-sided No.10.
Despite highlighting the gulf between academy football and the first-team stage at Brentford last weekend, Chido Obi is worthy of his second start and his first at Old Trafford.
He was tasked with leading the line last Sunday, replacing Hojlund, but he struggled to impose himself on proceedings in the way he would have liked.

However, at the tender age of 17, the only way the Dane is going to adapt to life at the highest level is by playing. Facing a West Ham side that have massively underperformed this season, Obi will fancy his chances of trying to flex his muscles a little more than he did last weekend.
With next to nothing riding on this game, what is the worst that can happen?

For the first time since leaving United last August, Aaron Wan-Bissaka will return to Old Trafford this afternoon. He joined West Ham almost a year ago in a deal worth £15million, signing a seven-year contract.
United always planned to sell Wan-Bissaka last summer in order to recoup a fee for the right-back. His exit also paved the way for Noussair Mazraoui to arrive from Bayern Munich.
Wan-Bissaka, who made 190 appearances during his time at United, has played 35 times for the Hammers this season, chipping in with two goals and three assists.
Producing an unexpected resurrection in the second half of the 2022/23 season under former United boss Erik ten Hag, the London-born defender should receive a warm reception from the home fans.

headline: Confirmed Manchester United squad members vs West Ham as youngsters included
body: Chido Obi is in contention to make his first Old Trafford start after being included in the Manchester United matchday squad for this afternoon's Premier League clash against West Ham United.
Obi made his full debut for United in last weekend's 4-3 defeat to Brentford at the Gtech Community Stadium following a handful of substitute appearances over the last few months.
